original_data.question: Twelve hours after undergoing an exploratory laparotomy for a perforated duodenal ulcer, a 36-year-old man has shortness of breath. He has asthma well controlled with an albuterol inhaler. His father died of lung cancer at 62 years of age. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 14 years. He does not drink alcohol. He appears uncomfortable. His temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 122/76 mm Hg. Examination shows reduced breath sounds over the left lung base. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. There is a clean, dry surgical incision over the midline of the abdomen. Bowel sounds are hypoactive. The calves are soft and nontender. His hemoglobin concentration is 12.9 g/dL, leukocyte count is 10,600/mm3, and platelet count is 230,000/mm3. An x-ray of the chest in supine position is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

model_response:
The x-ray shows a large amount of subcutaneous air in the left hemithorax. The subcutaneous air is causing the left lung to be partially collapsed. The collapsed lung is at the base, where the patient is having reduced breath sounds. The most likely cause of this patient's symptoms is atelectasis. Atelectasis is a common complication after abdominal surgery. It is caused by the collapse of lung tissue. The collapsed lung can be at the base or in the middle of the lung. The collapse can be partial or complete. The reduced breath sounds over the left base and the supine position make atelectasis the most likely diagnosis. Asthma exacerbation and pulmonary embolism would be unlikely to cause subcutaneous air. Pneumonitis is less likely because the patient does not have fever or an elevated white blood cell count.

###COMMENT: This patient has atelectasis. Atelectasis is a common complication after abdominal surgery. It is caused by the collapse of lung tissue. The collapsed lung can be at the base or in the middle of the lung. The collapse can be partial or complete. The reduced breath sounds over the left base and the supine position make atelectasis the most likely diagnosis.

###Answer: OPTION D IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Every twelve hours.
Surgical examination of the contents of the abdominal cavity as a means of diagnosis.
Human males as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
Height greater than two standard deviations below the mean of the appropriate reference population for the age and sex of the individual.
The air that is inhaled and exhaled during respiration.

A form of bronchial disorder with three distinct components: airway hyper-responsiveness (RESPIRATORY HYPERSENSITIVITY), airway INFLAMMATION, and intermittent AIRWAY OBSTRUCTION. It is characterized by spasmodic contraction of airway smooth muscle, WHEEZING, and dyspnea (DYSPNEA, PAROXYSMAL).

A short-acting beta-2 adrenergic agonist that is primarily used as a bronchodilator agent to treat ASTHMA. Albuterol is prepared as a racemic mixture of R(-) and S(+) stereoisomers. The stereospecific preparation of R(-) isomer of albuterol is referred to as levalbuterol.
A device by means of which a medicinal product can be administered by inspiration through the nose or the mouth.
Irreversible cessation of all bodily functions, manifested by absence of spontaneous breathing and total loss of cardiovascular and cerebral functions.
A primary or metastatic malignant neoplasm involving the lung.
A period of time that it takes for Earth to make a complete revolution around the sun, approximately 365 days; a specific one year period.
How long something has existed; elapsed time since birth.
Roll of dried and finely cut TOBACCO leaves wrapped in a cylinder of thin paper used for SMOKING.
Occurring or done each day.
A period of time that it takes for Earth to make a complete revolution around the sun, approximately 365 days; a specific one year period.

A clear, colorless liquid rapidly absorbed from the gastrointestinal tract and distributed throughout the body. It has bactericidal activity and is used often as a topical disinfectant. It is widely used as a solvent and preservative in pharmaceutical preparations as well as serving as the primary ingredient in ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES.
The measure of the level of heat of a human or animal.
The rhythmical expansion and contraction of an ARTERY produced by waves of pressure caused by the ejection of BLOOD from the left ventricle of the HEART as it contracts.

The act of breathing with the LUNGS, consisting of INHALATION, or the taking into the lungs of the ambient air, and of EXHALATION, or the expelling of the modified air which contains more CARBON DIOXIDE than the air taken in (Blakiston's Gould Medical Dictionary, 4th ed.). This does not include tissue respiration (= OXYGEN CONSUMPTION) or cell respiration (= CELL RESPIRATION).
PRESSURE of the BLOOD on the ARTERIES and other BLOOD VESSELS.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
Noises, normal and abnormal, heard on auscultation over any part of the RESPIRATORY TRACT.
A physical examination focusing on areas of interest other than the heart.
The action of removing dirt, filth, or unwanted substances from.
Removal of moisture from a substance (chemical, food, tissue, etc.).
A medial line, especially the medial line or medial plane of the body (or some part of the body).
That portion of the body that lies between the THORAX and the PELVIS.
Slow or diminished movement of body musculature. It may be associated with BASAL GANGLIA DISEASES; MENTAL DISORDERS; prolonged inactivity due to illness; and other conditions.
Lacking in hardness relatively or comparatively.

The mean cell hemoglobin concentration (MCHC), which is the average concentration of hemoglobin in a given volume of blood. The MCHC is a calculated value derived from the measurement of hemoglobin and the hematocrit.
The number of WHITE BLOOD CELLS per unit volume in venous BLOOD. A differential leukocyte count measures the relative numbers of the different types of white cells.
The number of PLATELETS per unit volume in a sample of venous BLOOD.
Used with organs, regions, and diseases for x-ray examinations.
The upper part of the trunk between the NECK and the ABDOMEN. It contains the chief organs of the circulatory and respiratory systems. (From Stedman, 25th ed)
The posture of an individual lying face up.

Fundamental claims of patients, as expressed in statutes, declarations, or generally accepted moral principles. (Bioethics Thesaurus) The term is used for discussions of patient rights as a group of many rights, as in a hospital's posting of a list of patient rights.
